div.head: New Yearʼs Poems
div.p: The two occasions that inspire poetry early in the Ruskin juvenilia and recur faithfully thoughout are John James Ruskin's May 10 birthday and New Yearʼs. Of the latter kind of occasional poem, whether inscribed for presentation on New Year's Eve or on New Year's Day, the earliest surviving example is “Time: Blank Verse”, which is dated ??? (see also “The Needless Alarm”: Discussion, for a poem earlier than "Time: Blank Verse", which may have been presented as a New Year's present, although it contains no formal features of an occasional ode).

A possible model for the New Year's ode, which was certainly available to Ruskih in the Herne Hill library, was the Evangelical Magazine, which regularly included a small section of New Year's poems in the January issue.

When this family tradition started is uncertain. The earliest poem specifically dated 1 January is . . . and the earliest poem explicitly connected with New Yearʼs Day is . . . “The Needless Alarm” and MS I as a whole. . . . The MS III Second Poetry Anthology contains at least three New Yearʼs Poems: “Time: Blank Verse,” the previous yearʼs presentation, along with “The Sun” and “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”).

Typically the poems contained a New Yearʼs greeting, but “Glen of Glenfarg” (“Papa how pretty those icicles are”) does not, suggesting that the relevance of a given topic to the holiday may have been understood only by the family.

One possible model for this practice was the Christmas and New Yearʼs annual, containing light verse and illustration, such as Friendshipʼs Offering.[When did the family start buying annuals? Point out how anthologies following “Harry and Lucy” may be imitating this.]
For a Scottish family, New Yearʼs Day . . . (What was the celebration typically? Why New Yearʼs?) Ruskin would always treat New Yearʼs as a red‐letter day connected with writing. . . .
